key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the long-term effects of using municipal waste compost on soil fertility over a 20-year period?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two controlled, replicated trials in Spain and the United Kingdom measured the effect of adding municipal wastes or composts from municipal wastes to the soil.
[Statement 2]: One trial found that adding municipal compost to semi-arid soils greatly reduced soil loss and water runoff.
[Statement 3]: Another trial found mixed results from adding composts and wastes to soil.
[Statement 4]: The soil types covered in the trials on municipal wastes were coarse loamy and sandy loam.
[Statement 5]: Two other controlled, replicated trials from Spain and the United Kingdom measured the effect of adding organic processing wastes or composts from organic processing wastes to soil.
[Statement 6]: One trial found that applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure.
[Statement 7]: A trial found that applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure reduced soil loss.
[Statement 8]: A trial found that applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure increased nutrient loss.
[Statement 9]: Another trial found improved nutrient retention when molasses were added to soil.
[Statement 10]: Another trial found increased barley Hordeum vulgare yield when molasses were added to soil.
[Statement 11]: The soil types covered in trials on organic processing wastes were sandy-clay, sandy loam, and silty-clay.
